}

Hereâ€™s a simple pattern to log the result or error:

```java
import android.util.Log; // add if not imported

// ... inside your class ...
private static final String TAG = "MainViewModel";

private void executeUseCase() {
 disposable.add(
 getWeatherUseCase.execute(new GetWeatherUseCase.Params(3.2, 76, 7))
 .observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())
 .subscribe(
 response -> Log.d(TAG, "Weather response: " + response),
 throwable -> Log.e(TAG, "Error getting weather", throwable)
 )
 );
}
```

**Note:** 
- String concatenation with the object will invoke its `toString()`; you may wish to override it in your domain/model classes for better output.

package com.javaweatherapp.presentation.viewmodel;

import android.util.Log;
import androidx.lifecycle.MutableLiveData;
import androidx.lifecycle.ViewModel;
import com.javaweatherapp.domain.model.WeatherInfo;
import com.javaweatherapp.domain.usecase.GetWeatherUseCase;
import dagger.hilt.android.lifecycle.HiltViewModel;
import io.reactivex.rxjava3.android.schedulers.AndroidSchedulers;
import io.reactivex.rxjava3.disposables.CompositeDisposable;
import javax.inject.Inject;

@HiltViewModel
public class MainViewModel extends ViewModel {

 private final GetWeatherUseCase getWeatherUseCase;
 private final CompositeDisposable composite = new CompositeDisposable();

 public final MutableLiveData<WeatherInfo> weatherInfo = new MutableLiveData<>();
 @Inject
 public MainViewModel(GetWeatherUseCase getWeatherUseCase) {
 this.getWeatherUseCase = getWeatherUseCase;
 }

 public void fetchWeatherInfo() {
 composite.add(
 getWeatherUseCase.execute(new GetWeatherUseCase.Params(3.2,76, 7))
 .observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())
 .subscribe(weatherInfo::setValue,
 throwable -> Log.e("TAG", "Error getting weather", throwable)
 ));
 }

 public void dispose() {
 composite.dispose();
 }
}

package com.javaweatherapp.presentation.adapter;

import android.view.LayoutInflater;
import android.view.View;
import android.view.ViewGroup;
import android.widget.TextView;
import androidx.annotation.NonNull;
import androidx.annotation.Nullable;
import androidx.recyclerview.widget.RecyclerView;
import com.javaweatherapp.R;
import com.javaweatherapp.domain.model.WeatherInfoItem;
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

public class WeatherAdapter extends RecyclerView.Adapter<WeatherAdapter.WeatherViewHolder> {
 private final List<WeatherInfoItem> items = new ArrayList<>();

 @NonNull
 @Override
 public WeatherViewHolder onCreateViewHolder(@NonNull ViewGroup parent, int viewType) {
 View view =
 LayoutInflater.from(parent.getContext()).inflate(R.layout.item_weather, parent, false);
 return new WeatherViewHolder(view);
 }

 @Override
 public void onBindViewHolder(@NonNull WeatherViewHolder holder, int position) {
 holder.bind(items.get(position));
 }

 @Override
 public int getItemCount() {
 return items.size();
 }

 public void setItems(@NonNull List<WeatherInfoItem> newItems) {
 items.clear();
 items.addAll(newItems);
 notifyDataSetChanged();
 }

 static class WeatherViewHolder extends RecyclerView.ViewHolder {
 TextView textTemp, textTempMin, textTempMax, textDescription;

 WeatherViewHolder(@NonNull View itemView) {
 super(itemView);
 textTemp = itemView.findViewById(R.id.textTemp);
 textTempMin = itemView.findViewById(R.id.textTempMin);
 textTempMax = itemView.findViewById(R.id.textTempMax);
 textDescription = itemView.findViewById(R.id.textDescription);
 }

 void bind(WeatherInfoItem item) {
 textTemp.setText("Temp: " + item.getTemp());
 textTempMin.setText("Min: " + item.getTempMin());
 textTempMax.setText("Max: " + item.getTempMax());
 textDescription.setText(""); // No description in WeatherInfoItem currently
 }
 }
}

</user_query>"}]},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The warning about `notifyDataSetChanged()` in your `WeatherAdapter.java` is common and generally harmless, but it points out that this method refreshes the entire listâ€”even if only one item was updated, added, or removed. This can be inefficient, especially for large lists.

### Why the warning?
- Android Studio (and linters) recommend using more efficient methods like `notifyItemInserted()`, `notifyItemRemoved()`, or `notifyItemChanged()`. These methods allow RecyclerView to animate changes and optimize rendering.

### Is it a problem?
- For most use cases with small or infrequently updated lists, `notifyDataSetChanged()` is perfectly fine.
- If your data set can grow large or update incrementally, you may want to consider a DiffUtil or the mentioned notify methods for optimal performance.

### Quick Fix & Advanced Recommendation:
- If your data is always completely replaced (as with setItems()), continue using `notifyDataSetChanged()`.
- If you want to improve, implement DiffUtil for automatic differences computation.

#### Example:
You can suppress the warning if you know this is fine:
```java
@SuppressLint("NotifyDataSetChanged")
public void setItems(@NonNull List<WeatherInfoItem> newItems) {
 items.clear();
 items.addAll(newItems);
 notifyDataSetChanged();
}
```
Or, replace with `notifyItemRangeInserted`:
```java
items.clear();
items.addAll(newItems);
notifyItemRangeInserted(0, items.size()); // requires additional logic if removing old items
```
But true efficiency comes with DiffUtil.

### TL;DR 
You can safely ignore the warning for now, or add `@SuppressLint("NotifyDataSetChanged")` above the method if you want to silence the linter.

Would you like a DiffUtil implementation for automatic update efficiency, or would you prefer to suppress the warning and keep the code simple?"}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
